snippet: FIFA and the Canadian Soccer Association may have thought the issue of playing next year’s Women’s World Cup on artificial turf would go away, but their obstruction backfired Wednesday.
abstract: Juliet Macur Sports of the Times column holds that obstructionist strategy by FIFA and Canadian Soccer Assn, when faced with request by some of world's best female soccer players to play 2015 summer World Cup on grass instead of artificial turf, has backfired on both organizations; says players simply asked to be heard, but wall of indifference from FIFA and the CSA led to gender discrimination lawsuit that now cannot be ignored.
lead_paragraph: FIFA and the Canadian Soccer Association may have thought the issue of playing next year’s Women’s World Cup on artificial turf would go away, but their obstruction backfired Wednesday.

headline.seo: Women's Soccer Stars Sue FIFA and Canadian Soccer Association Over Artificial Surfaces
headline.main: Playing Nice on Turf Issue, Only to Face a Wall of Indifference
headline.print_headline: Playing Nice on Turf Issue, Only to Face a Wall of Indifference
